title: Hundred expansion a ‚Äòno-brainer‚Äô if investment succeeds, predicts ECB chief
description: Auction has brought injection of ¬£520m to English cricketRichard Gould insists control of structure stays with ECBEnglish cricket bosses believe that it will be ‚Äúalmost a no-brainer‚Äù to expand the Hundred after raising more than ¬£520m by selling a stake in each of the competition‚Äôs eight teams.The England and Wales Cricket Board announced on Thursday that the eight bids had placed a total enterprise value of just over ¬£975m on the Hundred teams ‚Äì with ¬£520m being injected into the professional and recreational game. Continue reading...
author: Sean Ingle

title: McCullum insists England did ‚Äòlots of training‚Äô amid criticism of work ethic
description: England did not train between second and third ODIsDuckett faces scan but Smith and Overton recoveringBrendon McCullum has hit out at criticism of England‚Äôs training schedule after his side‚Äôs work ethic was brought into question during their 3-0 one-day international series defeat by India, insisting his players have done ‚Äúlots of training‚Äù.England‚Äôs practice, or lack of it, was picked up on in commentary by Ravi Shastri and Kevin Pietersen during the final ODI, with the former India coach claiming to have heard that the visitors had only done one net session on the entire trip, ‚Äúif not any‚Äù. That specific claim is inaccurate ‚Äì ‚Äútotally incorrect,‚Äù McCullum said ‚Äì with England having held multiple sessions during the preceding Twenty20 series and before the first ODI. They did not train before the second and third ODIs, with a mounting injury list cited to explain the decision amid a demanding itinerary. Continue reading...

title: Buying A Hundred Franchise: Nikesh Arora from the consortium that's invested in London Spirit, on his love of cricket and the sport's future
description: This week, Nasser and Athers are joined by Nikesh Arora, CEO of Palo Alto Networks. During a big week of investment into The Hundred teams, he discusses leading the tech consortium that won the bidding war for London Spirit, and the value and impact of live sport. He also talks of his love of the game, and the future of English cricket.
author: Sky Sports

title: Rowing the Atlantic‚Ä¶for a laugh
description: A special episode as we‚Äôre joined by Tailenders Rob, Charlie and Rob who decided to row the Atlantic for a laugh‚Ä¶ and charity. Tales of capsizing, sea sickness, bum sores, Mattchin-like hallucinations, weight loss, marlin strikes, arguments and listening to the Tailenders back catalogue. Plus more ‚ÄôTat Modern‚Äô and the welcome return of ‚ÄòGeneral Cricketing Sadness‚Äô.
author: BBC Radio 5 Live

title: Chris Jordan
description: England bowler and World Cup winner Chris Jordan is our special guest. Plus, Mattchin has another round of Cricket Golf, more entries for the ‚Äô'Tat Modern‚Äô and plans are developing for #tailendersoftheworlduniteandtakeover Lord's in April.
author: BBC Radio 5 Live

title: Mumbai Indians: Jhulan Goswami and Charlotte Edwards on return of the WPL
description: Ahead of the third season of the Women's Premier League, Alison Mitchell, Jim Maxwell, and Charu Sharma hear from former England captain Charlotte Edwards and former India fast bowler Jhulan Goswami on what it‚Äôs like working together as coaches at Mumbai Indians after being great rivals in their playing days. Edwards, currently head coach at MI, also says she wants to ‚Äòhelp‚Äô English cricket and has urged the ECB to ‚Äòget in touch‚Äô. It comes as the organisation conducts a review into the Ashes defeat to Australia. Following the recent success of India‚Äôs U19 side at youth level, Jhulan gives her opinion on whether she thinks that victory in Malaysia can help lead the senior team to victory at the Women‚Äôs World Cup in Autumn. Image: Jhulan Goswami and Charlotte Edwards laughing whilst talking to each other on the field. (Credit: Mumbai Indians)
author: BBC World Service

title: 'How long will you ignore Afghanistan girls?'
description: Alison Mitchell, Clint Wheeldon and Charu Sharma are joined by the captain of the Afghanistan women‚Äôs XI who played an exhibition match last week in Melbourne. Nahida Sapan tells us about the day itself, whether the team have felt supported and tells us her thoughts on whether she would support a boycott of Afghanistan men's matches.In a recent statement the ICC said "The ICC remains closely engaged with the situation in Afghanistan and continues to collaborate with our members,".. The governing body added it was their intention to "support the Afghanistan Cricket Board (ACB) in fostering cricket development and ensuring playing opportunities for both men and women in Afghanistan". An ICC working group, set up after the Taliban takeover in 2021, has met with representatives of the Afghanistan government and is keen to use its position and the sport of cricket to influence change in the country.Plus, Clint Wheeldon tells us how the Aussie triumph in the Women‚Äôs Ashes has been received in Australia and about the influence of spinner Alana King. We also hear from the Managing Director of England Women's Cricket Clare Connor on what she believes went wrong.And we ask if India coach Gautam Gambhir is beating England coach Brendon McCullum at his own game after their risky approach in the white ball series.Photo: Nahida Sapan, captain of Afghanistan Women's XI, leads out her teammates before the cricket match between Afghanistan Women's XI and Cricket Without Borders XI at Junction Oval in Melbourne on January 30, 2025. (Photo by MARTIN KEEP/AFP via Getty Images)
author: BBC World Service

title: How do England look heading into the Champions Trophy?
description: Henry Moeran is joined by Test Match Special commentators Daniel Norcross and Aatif Nawaz to preview the Champions Trophy.We examine England‚Äôs recent ODI series in India and their chances for the tournament. We also break down how the competition is going to work with a hybrid model being used, and also have a look at how all the other squads are shaping up as well.Make sure you‚Äôre subscribed to TMS wherever you listen to your podcasts - we‚Äôll have regular episodes around the Champions Trophy, including a look back on the last edition in 2017.
author: BBC Radio 5 Live

title: The Hundred‚Äô sales Pt 2: Hear from London Spirit Owner Nikesh Arora
description: Henry Moeran is joined by the BBC‚Äôs Chief Cricket Reporter Stephan Shemilt, and also the BBC‚Äôs Sport Editor Dan Roan.We hear from Nikesh Arora, the leader the consortium of tech billionaires who has agreed the vast fee of ¬£145 million pounds for a 49% share of the London Spirit.We‚Äôll also get into the details of the two latest sales as well; the Trent Rockets to a group involving Chelsea owner Todd Boehly, and Southern Brave to the Hampshire owners, the GMR group, who also own Delhi Capitals. This, therefore, effectively gives them full control of the Brave.Make sure you‚Äôre subscribed to TMS wherever you listen to your podcasts - we‚Äôll have regular podcasts around the Champions Trophy, including a look back on the last edition in 2017.
author: BBC Radio 5 Live
